element.name: none
element.field: A campaign pamphlet of the Volunteer Ticket, which is made up of African-American candidates, August 1959. Page 1 includes pictures of Russell Sugarmon, Commissioner of Public Works; Ben Hooks, Juvenile Court Judge; Henry Bunton and Roy Love, Board of Education. Page 2 is an article by George W. Lee, "The Negro's Position in the August Election," giving reasons for supporting the Volunteer Ticket; Lee is Chairman of the Steering Committee of the Volunteer Ticket. Page 3, entitled "What the Volunteer Candidates Stand For," is a list of issues the four candidates embrace. It concludes with the phrase, "The Negro Has a Love Affair with Destiny." Page 4 is a get-out-the-vote notice aimed at blacks, and includes the phrase "Don't Listen to 'Uncle Tom's'."

element.name: none
element.field: Pamphlet for the Memphis Election - Volunteer Ticket

element.name: none
element.field: This is a program for the Kennedy Memorial Service, Sunday, November 24, 1963. Following the assassination of John F. Kennedy, The Shelby County Democratic Executive Committee conducted a memorial service at Ellis Auditorium. Participants included Russell B. Sugarmon, John Ford Canale, Lucius Burch, Lewis Donelson, Ben Hooks, Rabbi James Wax, Rev. Paul Caudill, Monsignor Merlin Kearney, and Margarite Piazza Condon.

element.name: none
element.field: Program In Memoriam, His Excellency John Fitzgerald Kennedy, President of the United States of America

element.name: none
element.field: A memo to Russell Sugarmon from Johnnie Turner detailing the panel members, S. B. Kyles and Maxine Smith and the upcoming discussion on civil rights and its legal issues.

element.name: none
element.field: Memo to Russell Sugarmon from Johnnie Turner

element.name: none
element.field: A biographical sketch of Russell B. Sugarmon's life and professional career. The document contains information about Sugarmon's education, military service, family, church, awards received, and past memberships and activities.

element.name: none
element.field: Biography of Honorable Russell B. Sugarmon, General Session Civil Judge, Division IV

element.name: none
element.field: A news release from Fred Davis and Rufus Jones. Davis and Jones were removed from their positions as auditors for the State Department of Revenue by Commissioner Donald King. The two men dispute public claims that their job performance was not satisfactory and suggest that they were removed because African-American organizations to which they belonged supported the governor's opponent, Ross Bass, in the August 6 primary election for the United States Senate.

element.name: none
element.field: Immediate Press Release Regarding the Firing of Fred Davis and Rufus Jones from the State Department of Revenue

element.name: none
element.field: A sample ballot of the Shelby County Democratic Club, Fall 1960.

element.name: none
element.field: Pamphlet from the John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson Campaign

element.name: none
element.field: A one-page list containing the officers of the Tennessee Voters' Council. It comes from the year of 1964 and starts with the General Chairman, and includes all officers down to the Assistant Parliamentarian. There is also a section at the bottom for the Board of Directors which lists the direct representatives for the first and second congressional districts. The chairmen at the time were Charles F. Williams, Reverend Frank Gordon, Attorney Avon Willams, and Attorney R. B. Sugarmon.

element.name: none
element.field: Tennessee Voters' Council, List of Officers

element.name: none
element.field: This is a short synopsis and biography of Russell Sugarmon Jr.

element.name: none
element.field: Brief Biographical Sketch of Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr. (Second)

element.name: none
element.field: A photograph of Russell Sugarmon and other unknown officials participating in the presentation of a certificate

element.name: none
element.field: Photograph of Russell B. Sugarmon and unknown officials

element.name: none
element.field: This document is continuation of the description of Russell B. Sugarmon's work experience. It specifically lists several civil rights cases that he filed and tried alongside such people as Thurgood Marshall.

element.name: none
element.field: A letter from J.M Moseley to the Shelby County Democratic Club requesting Moseley and the club support convenient voting for African American voters.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from J. M. Moseley to Shelby County Democratic Club

element.name: none
element.field: Meeting notes for Citizens Non-Partisan Registration Committee.

element.name: none
element.field: In this letter to Maxine Smith, Russell Sugarmon offers her a word of encouragement.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr. to Maxine Smith

element.name: none
element.field: Henry Beaty, Jr. asks T.H. Hayes, Jr. to give an account of Russell Sugarmon, Jr.'s character and education, so the Bar Association can determine whether or not Sugarmon should be allowed to practice law in Memphis.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Attorney Henry M. Beaty, Jr. to T.H. Hayes, Jr

element.name: none
element.field: Budget Committee of the Citizens Non-Partisan Voter Registration Committee

element.name: none
element.field: A long memo by the Citizens Non-Partisan Registration Campaign, which was established in 1948 by black leaders of the Democratic and Republican parties to increase minority registration. This document reviews their efforts to register black voters since 1948 (a two page section provides historical information on black and white enrollments for this period) and outlines plans for publicity and door-to-door canvassing for the 1962 election. It was submitted by Jesse H. Turner, A. W. Willis, Jr., Russell B. Sugarmon, B. L. Hooks, S. A. Wilbun.

element.name: none
element.field: Organizational Plans for Citizens Non-Partisan Voters Registration Campaign for 1962 in Shelby County

element.name: none
element.field: This document is a list of officers of the Shelby County Democratic Club.

element.name: none
element.field: Officers of the Shelby County Democratic Club

element.name: none
element.field: A letter from Roy Wilkins to Jesse H. Turner, February 27, 1961. Wilkins, Executive Secretary of the NAACP, congratulating Turner for the Commercial Appeal ad as an excellent piece of public relations.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Roy Wilkins, Executive Secretary, to Mr. Jesse H. Turner, President Memphis Branch NAACP

element.name: none
element.field: A letter of recommendation for Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr. to be admitted to the bar in Memphis and Shelby County. The author commends his ability, character, and family background.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from T.H. Hayes, Jr. to Attorney Henry M. Beaty Jr

element.name: none
element.field: Agenda for the Shelby County Democratic club.

element.name: none
element.field: Agenda of Shelby County Democratic Club Meeting (Dec. 15, 1958)

element.name: none
element.field: A letter from E.V Braswell to A.W. Willis, Jr., concerning materials needed in multiple counties to strengthen support from a number of candidates. Braswell also speaks of the need to secure the votes of the growing amount of African American voters and the attempt to support Earl Macklin.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from E.V. Braswell to A. W. Willis Tennessee Voters' Council

element.name: none
element.field: A letter from Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr. to Hon. Albert C. Gore, November 6, 1961. He requests that Gore meet with the Shelby County Democratic Club to discuss some troublesome problems. The letter is copied to Sen. Estes Kefauver.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr., Attorney to Hon. Albert C. Gore

element.name: none
element.field: An election poster in support of Russell Sugarmon, who was campaigning for the County Court in an election to be held on May 17, 1976. This poster emphasizes his long record of service.

element.name: none
element.field: Flyer to Elect Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr. to County Court

element.name: none
element.field: A letter from Secretary of State Dean Rusk to Russell Sugarmon. Rusk asks Sugarmon to represent the United States at the ceremonies celebrating the independence of Trinidad and Tobago in September; an enclosure lists other members of the US delegation, including Charles C. Diggs, Jr., U. S. Congressman from Michigan.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Dean Rusk to B. Russell Sugarmon, Jr.

element.name: none
element.field: A short memo detailing the agenda of a meeting of the Shelby County Democratic Club.

element.name: none
element.field: Agenda for Shelby County Democratic Club

element.name: none
element.field: This letter, copied to Russell B. Sugarmon Jr. and four other leaders of the Volunteer Organization, acknowledges an agreement that Armour will support the appointment of A. W. Willis to the Memphis Transit Authority.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Claude A. Armour Jr. Commissioner of Fire & Police to Mr. A. Maceo Walker

element.name: none
element.field: A list of contacts, including address and phone numbers, for Baptist ministers in the Memphis area.

element.name: none
element.field: A Resolution adopted by the Tennessee Voters' Council addressed to the Hon. Frank G. Clement, Governor of the State of Tennessee. The resolution condemns the firing of Fred Davis and Rufus Jones, asks the Governor to investigate their case and reinstate them, encourages him to support the appointment of minorities to state offices, and urges that political loyalties not be a basis for holding administrative positions in Tennessee.

element.name: none
element.field: Resolution to the Honorable Frank G. Clement, Governor of the State of Tennessee, from the Tennessee Voters Council

element.name: none
element.field: A campaign letter from Russell Sugarmon and A. W. Willis, Jr. to Dear Fellow Citizen. Mailed widely, along with a platform statement and biographical sketches just prior to the election, it expresses pride in the way Memphians are adjusting to racial change and mentions the need for Negroes to be present in the state legislature.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr. and A. W. Willis, Jr. to Fellow Citizens

element.name: none
element.field: This pamphlet, published by the NAACP at the height of the Red Scare in the mid 1950's, stresses the organization's opposition to communism and its commitment to democratic values. The cover is emblazoned with an American flag. It is specifically directed at those supporters of segregation who have tried to falsely link the NAACP with the Communist party.

element.name: none
element.field: A letter from Hubert H. Humphrey to Russell Sugarmon. The Vice President of the United States sends greetings, and wishes Sugarmon a speedy recovery from his injuries. He requests that Sugarmon keep him informed about happenings in Memphis.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Hubert Humphrey to Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr.

element.name: none
element.field: This letter from the Assistant Postmaster General of the U.S. in Washington DC provides a numerical ranking of the "Negro employees" of the Post Office in Memphis.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Richard J. Murphy to Mr. Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr.

element.name: none
element.field: This is a letter to Louie Martin of the Demoncratic National Committee from Avon Williams Jr., President of the Davidson County Independent Political Council and Co-Chair of the Tennessee Voter's Council. Louie discusses his intention to distribute copies of a letter he wrote on September 29, 1964 to notable people, including Russell B. Sugarmon and A.W. Willis.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Avon Williams to Louie Martin

element.name: none
element.field: An agenda containing the order of business for a meeting of the Shelby County Democratic Club on April 21, 1960.

element.name: none
element.field: Agenda of Shelby County Democratic Club

element.name: none
element.field: A special report on Political Action by Hugh T. It describes the work being done to promote voter participation in ten rural counties of West Tennessee.

element.name: none
element.field: A letter written by Claude A. Armour, Memphis Vice Mayor and Commissioner of Fire and Police, inviting Mr. Russell B. Sugarman to the first graduation exercises of an African-American police class.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Claude A. Armour, Commissioner of Fire & Police to Mr. Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr., Attorney

element.name: none
element.field: This letter notifies members of the Tennessee Voters' Council of two upcoming meetings. The first will be held at Lane College in Jackson to discuss the next summer's election. The second is the state-wide meeting in Nashville at Fisk University.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from R. B. Sugarmon, Jr., Chairman Tennessee Voters' Council to Fellow Tennesseans

element.name: none
element.field: Details the life of W. O. Walker, recounting the success of his newspaper, the Call and Post, and his political activity. The article sits next to photos of Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr., O. Z. Evers, and L. C. Bates, who are recognized by the Chicago Defender for their work in civil rights.

element.name: none
element.field: Sugarmon, Evers, Bates Get Coveted Honors - Cited for Efforts in Arena of Civil Rights

element.name: none
element.field: This document is a biographical sketch of A. W. Willis, Jr.

element.name: none
element.field: Biographical Sketch of A.W. Willis, Jr

element.name: none
element.field: A letter from Democratic National Committee Member, Billie Carr to his fellow members of the DNC. He is informing the members about the future business of the committee in the upcoming conferences, campaigns and elections.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Billie Carr, DNC Texas to National Committee Members

element.name: none
element.field: A letter from Lucius E. Burch to Paul Tudor Jones. Burch strongly opposed the suggestion that Russell Sugarmon be removed from the subcommittee on libraries of the Memphis Committee on Community Relations because of the fact that Sugarmon had recently been retained by the NAACP as legal counsel. For Burch, Sugarmon's involvement with the NAACP only strengthened his importance to the committee.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Lucius Burch, Jr. to Dr. Paul Tudor Jones

element.name: none
element.field: A letter from Russell Sugarmon to Paul Butler. Sugarmon requests a personal meeting with Butler, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, to discuss relations between Negroes and the Shelby County Democratic Committee.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Russell B. Sugarmon Jr. to Paul Butler

element.name: none
element.field: Tennessee Voters' Council, East Tennessee Office

element.name: none
element.field: This statement from the Tennessee Voters' Council observes the lack of support for Senator Ross Bass from Mr.Bullard and Mr. Clement after they repudiated his stance on the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

element.name: none
element.field: Statement from the Tennessee Voters' Council

element.name: none
element.field: Joe S. Taylor is reporting on recent events concerning the elections in District Nine of Memphis in this handwritten letter.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Joe S. Taylor to A. W. Willis

element.name: none
element.field: A letter from Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr. and A. W. Willis, Jr. to Wade H. Sides, Jr. On November 14, 1962, Sugarmon, Willis, and their wives were refused admission to a production of "Gypsy" at the Front Street Theatre; they had been encouraged to buy season tickets because the Theatre had adopted a new policy of non-discrimination. Sides and Attorney Hunter Lane met with the two men and explained that the policy was reversed because admitting blacks had diminished ticket sales. The letter calls for a full vote of the theatre's board of governors and chastises well-educated Memphians for practicing discrimination at a time when blacks are accepted at wrestling matches and jazz events without incident.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr., Attorney to Mr. Wade H. Sides, Jr.

element.name: none
element.field: This document is H.T. Lockhard's resume. It describes his education and other accomplishments that demonstrate his ability to complete a task.

element.name: none
element.field: A letter to A. W. Willis from C. B. Robinson concerning upcoming plans for the campaign of the candidate, Ross Bass. This letter also commends A. W. Willis on a previous position that he took against Govenor Clements.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from C. B. Robinson , President, Tenneesee Voters Council to A. W. Willis, Secretary, Tennessee Voters Council

element.name: none
element.field: A biographical sketch of Russell B. Sugarmon that was written to be included in a book called Notable Black Memphians by Miriam DeCosta Willis (Laurie). There are corrections that have been made by Russell B. Sugarmon included in the document and a thank you note at the bottom from the author

element.name: none
element.field: Biographical Sketch of Sugarmon for Notable Black Memphians, by Miriam Decosta-Willis

element.name: none
element.field: A letter from Lyndon B. Johnson to Russell Sugarmon.The Vice President of the United States, addressing the letter to "my dear friend," thanks Sugarmon for his hard work and contributions to the first annual Regional Community Leaders Conference held in St. Louis on June 26.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from Lyndon B. Johnson to Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr.

element.name: none
element.field: This document gives descriptions of those who are eligible for an absentee ballot and the process of applying for one.

element.name: none
element.field: The Commercial Appeal [from Jesse H. Turner, President, Memphis Branch NAACP]

element.name: none
element.field: A memo addressed to President Kennedy which appeared as a full page ad in the Commercial Appeal, February 22, 1961, sponsored by the Memphis chapter of the NAACP. It asks the new President to make all the rights and opportunities of American democracy available to "Negroes in Memphis." Signed by Jesse H. Turner, President, and (Rev) H. C. Nabrit, Chair of Freedom Committee.

element.name: none
element.field: Re: A Modest Proposal for the Annexation of the City of Memphis, Shelby County, Tennessee [To: President John Fitzgerald Kennedy and Loyal American Citizens Everywhere]

element.name: none
element.field: A resume of Russell B. Sugarmon's education and professional career.

element.name: none
element.field: Brief Biographical Sketch of Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr. (First)

element.name: none
element.field: This clipping marks the 25th anniversary of the 1959 campaign for the Volunteer Ticket; it notes that Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr., Benjamin Hooks and others attracted nationwide attention even though they lost.

element.name: none
element.field: News of Bygone Days [25 Years Ago, Aug. 22.1959]

element.name: none
element.field: An Open Letter from the Tennessee Voters' Council addressed to citizens of Middle Tennessee. The letter endorses Rep. Ross Bass in his race against Gov. Frank Clement for the United States Senate. Bass is applauded for supporting the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and recent tax cuts, while Clement is cited for his failures as Governor on human rights and economic policy. The letterhead identifies Russell Sugarmon and Willis as leaders of the statewide organization.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from the Tennessee Voters' Council to the Citizens of Middle Tennessee

element.name: none
element.field: A letter from H. T. Lockard to A. W. Willis, Jr. Lockard, President of the 9th District Democratic League, writes to suggest a meeting of leaders from the many different factions within the black community. Lockard hopes to create unity for the upcoming elections.

element.name: none
element.field: Letter from H. T. Lockard, President, Tennessee Federation of Democratic Leagues, Inc. to A. W. Willis, Jr., Esq.

element.name: none
element.field: An editorial by Eugene A. Luening where he expresses his displeasure with the legal segregation of public facilities (in this case the library) in Memphis

element.name: none
element.field: The City Commission Should Correct Library Injustice

element.name: none
element.field: A campaign brochure for Russell B. Sugarmon, Jr. and A.W. Willis, Jr. Entitled "We Need Negroes in State Government." It headlines the phrase "If Georgia Can Do It So Can We," referring to the recent victory of Julian Bond in Atlanta. Sugarmon is a candidate for the State Senate, Willis for the State House of Representatives, both referred to as "Freedom Fighters." Their nine-point joint platform highlights civil rights, womens rights, job creation, and education.

element.name: none
element.field: Campaign Brochure: We Need Negro Representation in State Government, Sugarmon and A.W. Willis
